# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is the Julia solution to your problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(str::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(str, " ")
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " " * word) > text_width
            result *= (line * "\n")
            line = word
        else
            line *= " "
            line *= word
        end
    end
    result *= line
    return result
end

println(wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines"))
```

When you run this code, it breaks the string `"This function will wrap words into lines"` at the specified width (default is 10). This is because each word is added to a line until that line's length exceeds the given `text_width`, at which point a new line is started with that word.
